I tried watching this movie but couldn't make out much of the dialog.  I can hear well enough but the mumbling slang was indecipherable to me.  I grew up with English and speak three languages reasonably well but the lingo here was as hard to follow as deep south Bavarian, Cockney, a Scottish brogue or Newfie English. If the southern accents are authentic, that's perhaps as it should be, but I found this movie unwatchable.  It might be worth another attempt when a subtitled version becomes available.

I like the movie. I liked it enough to say i like it. The one thing I found frustrating was the music.  Now, I don't know if it was like this at the theatres, but on Prime, it seemed very muffled and unorganized. The scenes were loosely connected, and the back stories didn't really do much for the narrative. I like Michael B Jordan, but this wasn't his best effort. The story of vampires is a subject that's difficult to tie to the early 1920s time period. His attempt was a valiant effort indeed. I give it 2 1/2 out of 5. It's still a good movie to lose yourself in, if only for 125 minutes.

   Of this film, I thought, I was watching, a docu-drama about, Black Coulture.

I just watched Sinners yesterday morning and then again in the evening to catch what I may have missed during the first watch. I liked it more the second time I saw it, maybe because I paid more attention to the symbolism. Glad I didnâ€™t watch the trailer because it showed entirely too much. 

Side note: back in 1999 I saw The Matrix in theaters; I hadnâ€™t seen a trailer or had any knowledge of what it was about. Just that Keanu Reeves was in it and I loved it! So I donâ€™t like to watch trailers really, Iâ€™ll view a few seconds and then turn it off so it doesnâ€™t spoil the movie.
Finally a great movie! Well done, folks! I want to see more of this original stories, with a bold cinematic approach, great story, great music and great acting!

I don't normally want to see vampire movies / films, but I've seen enough very excellent movies made by Black directors and Black actors, addressing serious issues, that I had to see "Sinners." Once again, even at age 69, I paced nervously in my living room while the blood-suckers were doing their thing, but by that time, the movie and actors had proven themselves over and over again. Every scene, amazing talent.
I haven't seen it yet but it's on my list now. I feel like this plot may be similar to "From Dusk till Dawn" but let me know if I'm wrong.

I find it interesting that the media said this movie was a success with a big asterisk because it made I think it was 2/3 of its entire budget back opening weekend like it was some sort of failure but all I've seen is people raving about it, countless reaction videos and folks saying they've seen it 2, 3, 4 times and WANT to go see it again. Why did they seem to want to downplay it like they did? Especially from a director who has several hugely successful movies on his resume. That doesn't happen with other directors. He so damn fine. I knew he would give us Denzel vibes when he first got famous. But the fact the he takes every role so seriously makes me excited for black cinema to continueğŸ¥° I was iffy for a sec.

This movie was incredible!! We just left the theater, and my boyfriend and I couldnâ€™t stop talking about the â€œdancing through timeâ€ sceneâ€”it completely blew us away. It was more than just beautiful choreography; it was a powerful visual journey through Black history and culture. From traditional African rhythms to modern-day movements like hip-hop and twerking, every step told a story of resilience, evolution, and identity.

It captured the spirit of generations in just a few minutes, and I honestly havenâ€™t stopped thinking about it. That scene alone makes the entire film unforgettable.

I think the theme you were looking for of music being able to save the group was shown by music being what gathered them together in the first place. It is what allowed them to team up, trust each other, and fight the vampiric threat.
